abstract.p: This article presents the design equations for an on–off shape memory alloy actuator working against an external system of arbitrary constant forces. A binary shape memory alloy actuator is considered where a cursor is moved against both conservative and dissipative forces, which may be different during the push or pull phase. Three cases are analysed and differentiated in the way the bias force is applied to the primary shape memory alloy spring: using a constant force, a conventional spring or a second shape memory alloy spring. Closed-form dimensionless design equations are developed, which form the basis of a step-by-step procedure for an optimal design of the whole actuator.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Shape memory alloys (SMAs) have become an industrial valuable choice in the engineering world because of their many assets. Pseudoplasticity, superelasticity and shape memory effect (Mavroidis et al., 2000) are useful in several of the applications, including actuators, constant-force springs and solid-state damping systems. This article deals only with the shape memory effect that enables the SMAs to recover a memorized shape when heated. This effect is promoted by the transition from martensite to austenite, the two phases of SMAs. SMAs are martensitic below martensite finish temperature (Mf) and austenitic above austenite finish temperature (Af) as reported by Liang and Rogers (1997). This transition phenomenon leads to a change in the elastic modulus, which can be exploited to build actuators. While the phenomena related to SMA are theoretically well known, there is still a need for engineering methods to assist the designer in transforming these alloys into industrial devices (see Appendix 1 for nomenclature).

Many applications based on SMAs have been studied in recent years. Kuribayashi (1989) proposes a rotary joint based on a bending SMA actuator, while, Khidir et al., (2007) present a linear SMA actuator. Microrobots can be developed using SMA as shown by Kim et al., (2006). Tobushi and Tanaka (1991) try to formalize a basic method to design the SMA spring based on a thermoelectromechanical approach, and Reynaerts and Van Brussel (1998) present design considerations concerning the choice of the active element to evaluate SMA actuator efficiency. It is possible to take into account pseudoplasticity as done by Lu et al., 1997 but this leads to complex design considerations. Due to high non-linearity, Bergamasco et al., (1990) proposed design curves based on experiments to assess the SMA actuator geometry. Recently, Meier and Czechowicz (in press) proposed an experimental based thermomechanical model to describe SMA dynamic with a numerical procedure for the design of SMA actuators.

Despite the wealth of articles dealing with the use of SMA elements to generate motion and produce work, a systematic and complete procedure that can assist with the design of shape memory actuators has not yet been completely developed. The methods adopted to design and to proportion SMA actuators are either tailored to specific applications or poorly formalized from a quantitative point of view. Furthermore, there is little on how to achieve the best design for these kinds of actuators.

In an attempt to overcome these limitations, in a former article, Spinella and Dragoni (2009) proposed an analytical procedure for the design of binary SMA actuators. The procedure applies both to the ideal conditions of no external forces on the actuator (positioning application) and to the more realistic situation of a finite dissipative force resisting the motion of the actuator. The main limitation of this procedure is represented by the resisting force being constant in both the actuation directions. Moreover, the procedure needs empirical data for specific applications in order to take into account the change of SMA characteristics during cycling.

In this study, the design procedure is developed further and made more straightforward and general. A generic actuator is considered that makes the cursor move by means of an elastic system containing an active SMA spring and a bias (backup) element. Three characteristic cases are analysed and differentiated in the way the bias forces are provided to the active SMA spring: using a constant force, a conventional spring or another SMA spring, as proposed by Huang (2002) (Figure 1). A combination of dissipative forces and of conservative forces acting against the moving part of the system is included in the model. This combination of forces is able to cover all the most frequent cases of actuation. Closed-form relationships are developed, which form the basis of a step-by-step procedure for an optimal design of the entire actuator (active and bias element).

sec.title: Method
sec.p: An actuator containing at least one primary spring made of SMAs was considered. In addition to the primary SMA spring, the actuator also contains a restoring element, which provides a bias force acting against the primary SMA spring. According to the particular means of applying the bias force, the three cases shown in Figure 1 were analysed:

list-item.p: A primary SMA spring biased by a constant force;
A primary SMA spring biased by a conventional spring;
A primary SMA spring biased by another SMA spring (when one spring is hot and the other one is cold, and vice versa)

sec.p: Without the loss of generality, each spring in Figure 1 is modelled as a traction spring exhibiting a linear force–deflection relationship. The assumption of linearity is taken for granted for the conventional bias spring in Figure 1(b), but the linear behaviour is by no means obvious for the SMA springs in the actuator. The same explanation given by Spinella and Dragoni (2009) is thus considered. Since this analysis is aimed at dimensioning the binary actuator for the extreme positions, irrespective of the intermediate state, the behaviour of the material is described in Figure 2 by segments OA′ and OC. The reference elastic moduli for martensite and austenite are EM and EA, respectively. The change in the elastic modulus between the two temperatures determines a consequent change in the stiffness of the SMA springs. This modification, which occurs upon the activation/deactivation of the SMA spring(s), varies the equilibrium position of the cursor. This is also true if the shear behaviour of the shape memory material is considered, when the maximum shear strain, γadmS, replaces εadmS and the shear moduli GM and GA replace EM and EA, respectively.

caption.p: Simplified stress–strain behaviour of a shape memory alloy at different temperatures.

sec.p: It is well known that the force–displacement relationship for SMAs is speed dependent (Langbein et al., 2010) and so are the elastic properties referenced above. The speed effect would be particularly critical for proportional actuators in which the target position must be accurately controlled for any given external force. For the class of binary actuators covered in this article, the speed effect is less significant because the limit positions are defined by hard stops against which the material comes at rest, thus achieving long-term properties after each travel from one position to the other. For this reason, in the following development, the elastic properties are those derived from quasi-static characterization of the alloy. These assumptions keep the design equations clear and straightforward, with minor losses from the engineering standpoint.

Each actuator presented in Figure 1 is intended to move cursor E (mechanical output port) through a total useful stroke Δx when working against an external dissipative force FF and an external conservative force F0 (taken positive when acts against the primary SMA element).

The force FF is always opposite to the velocity of the cursor and is assumed to be constant. For example, if the cursor is subject to dry friction forces characterized by a static value FS and a dynamic value FD < FS, as reported by Stolarski (1990), the design dissipative force FF = MAX(FS, FD) = FS will be adopted for the calculation.

This approach comprises every possible external constant load, as exemplified by the membrane pump shown in Figure 3. This example represents the most general case of external constant forces the actuator has to deal with. The SMA actuator undergoes the following external loads: two generic dissipative forces F1 (force during aspiration) and F2 (force during pumping) and a conservative force Fu due to the gravity force on the piston. When the piston is moving towards the SMA primary spring (inlet of the fluid), the dissipative force F1 and the force Fu act together against the primary spring. By contrast, when the cursor moves away from the primary SMA spring (outlet of the fluid), the dissipative force F2 acts on the cursors against the force Fu and the primary spring. This force system can be always reduced to the two forces considered in the method: a conservative one, F0, and two symmetric dissipative ones, FF, rearranging the forces as follows

sec.p: Four important dimensionless parameters, s1, s2, sF and s0 were defined to simplify the development of design expressions. These parameters have a physical meaning too.
The first dimensionless parameter, s1, is a property of the SMA and is defined as the ratio between the hot stiffness, K1SH or K2SH, and the cold stiffness, K1SC or K2SC, of each SMA spring.

Assuming that the geometric changes related to the deformations of the springs do not influence the elastic constant value, s1 can also be expressed by the ratio between the above-defined austenite and martensite elastic moduli of the spring material as follows
Definition implies that if two antagonistic active springs are considered, they are made of the same SMA, identified by the same value of s1.

The second dimensionless parameter, s2, is useful in the configurations with two springs and is defined as the ratio between the minimum value assumed by the stiffness of bias spring 2 and the stiffness of active spring 1 in the cold state

The minimum value assumed by the stiffness of spring 2, K2min, coincides with the only stiffness of spring 2, K2C, if spring 2 is a conventional one, while it coincides with K2SC if spring 2 is an active one.

The third dimensionless parameter, sF, is introduced in order to consider the influence of the dissipative forces in the motion of the SMA actuator. This parameter is defined as the ratio between the design dissipative force FF and the maximum force sustained by the primary spring in the cold state, calculated as the product between the cold spring stiffness, K1SC, and the maximum deflection, LC−L01, in the cold state

The fourth dimensionless parameter, s0, is introduced in order to consider the influence of the conservative force in the motion of the SMA actuator. This parameter is defined as the ratio between the conservative force F0 and the maximum force sustained by the primary spring in the cold state, calculated as the product between the cold spring stiffness, K1SC, and the maximum deflection, LC−L01, in the cold state

The design procedure proposed in this article is divided into two steps. The first step provides general results, regardless of the particular type of spring embodying the actuator. The second includes the step-by-step procedure to enforce the actuator design. The input data for the first step consist of the overall stroke of the actuator (Δx), the design dissipative force (FF), the conservative force (F0) and the materials used for the SMA spring(s). Based on equilibrium considerations, the first step provides general design equations involving the dimensionless parameters introduced above. The output of the first step is provided in section ‘Results and discussion’. The input data for the second step consist of the type of the spring (e.g. helical spring, traction wire, Belleville spring). Based on standard formulas from machine design textbooks (Niemann, 1978; Shigley et al., 2004) and seeking for optimum conditions, the second step provides the procedure to proportion a real helical or wire spring (see Appendix 2) that is commonly used to embody the actuator.

Equations (6), (8), (12), (13) and (18) represent the fundamental design equations for the SMA actuator biased by a constant force. The typical design procedure can be outlined as follows:

list-item.p: The stroke of the actuator (Δx), the design dissipative force (FF) and the design conservative force (F0) are accepted from design specifications;
A shape memory material for the spring and a maximum strain, εadmS or γadmS, are selected, after which parameter s1 = EA/EM = GA/GM is known;
An sF value lower than the critical value (equation (11)) is chosen, possibly using equation (18);
The value of s0 is calculated using equation (6);
The bias force, FB, is calculated using equation (8);
The maximum deflection of the primary spring, LC−L01, is retrieved from equation (13);
The cold stiffness, K1SC, of the spring is calculated from equation (12).

sec.p: This procedure ensures that any actuator biased by the calculated constant force FB and containing whatever SMA spring with the selected material parameter s1 and calculated cold stiffness K1SC satisfies the design problem (useful stroke (Δx), design dissipative force (FF) and conservative force (F0)) if stretched by the amount LC−L01 in the cold state.
The primary SMA spring can be designed in detail according to a preferred geometry based on, for example, geometrical constraints or availability of stock material.

sec.p: When the springs are not connected and removed from each other by gap p, the hot SMA spring (spring 1) and the conventional spring (spring 2) assume their free lengths, L01 and L02, as shown in the top drawing in Figure 5(a). Equations (3), (4), (6), (8), (18), (20), (25) to (28) and (30) represent the fundamental design equations for the SMA actuator biased by a conventional spring. The typical design procedure can be outlined as follows:

list-item.p: The stroke of the actuator (Δx), the design dissipative force (FF) and the design conservative force (F0) are accepted from design specifications;
A shape memory material for the spring and a maximum strain, εadmS or γadmS, are selected, after which parameter s1 = EA/EM = GA/GM is known;
The spring embodiment is chosen, and the parameters ml1, ml2 and md1 are calculated as shown in Appendix 2. If the parameters cannot be determined, this step is skipped;

An sF value lower than the critical value (equation (27)) is selected. The parameter is chosen as small as possible to reduce the total size of the actuator, respecting the constraint of the diameter of the wire, d, given by equation (18);
The value of s0 is calculated using equation (6);

The lowest affordable value of parameter s2 is chosen (to exploit the primary spring); alternatively, the optimal value (equation (30)) is adopted (to conserve overall space). If the parameters ml1 and ml2 cannot be determined, equation (25) can be used for a sub-optimal design;
The maximum deflection of the primary spring, LC−L01, is retrieved from equation (26);
The cold stiffness, K1SC, of the spring is calculated from equation (4);
The overall pre-stretch of the system, p, is calculated from equation (20);
The stiffness of the conventional spring, KC, is calculated from equation (3);
The maximum deflection of the conventional spring, p−(LH−L01) is calculated from equation (28).

sec.p: This procedure ensures that any actuator biased by a conventional spring with the calculated stiffness KC and containing whatever SMA spring, with the selected material parameter s1 and the calculated cold stiffness K1SC, satisfies the design problem (useful stroke (Δx), design dissipative force (FF) and design conservative force (F0)) when assembled with the calculated pre-stretch p.

As shown in Appendix 2, the primary SMA spring and the conventional springs can be designed according to a preferred geometry based on, for example, geometrical constraints or availability of stock material.

sec.p: This procedure ensures that any actuator based on an agonist–antagonist SMA spring architecture with the calculated stiffness K2SC and containing whatever SMA spring, with the selected material parameter s1 and the calculated cold stiffness K1SC, satisfies the design problem (useful stroke (Δx), design dissipative force (FF) and design conservative force (F0)) when assembled with the calculated pre-stretch p. After the step-by-step procedure, the primary and secondary SMA springs can be designed according to a preferred geometry based on, for example, geometrical constraints or availability of the stock material.

sec.title: General comments
sec.p: The physical meaning of dimensionless design parameters s1, s2, sF and s0 deserves a specific comment. Parameter s1 is an intrinsic property of the SMA material chosen, so its value ranges from 2 to 4. The higher the s1, the better the SMA behaviour. It is possible to overcome the limitation going beyond the SMA elastic limit to increase s1, but fatigue issues must be carefully considered.

Parameter s2 = K2min/K1SC is a measure of the relative stiffness between the bias spring (be it conventional or SMA) and the primary SMA spring. Optimal values of parameter s2, which maximize the overall travel, depend on s1, sF and s0 and are also provided for different spring embodiments. Low values of s2 lead to an increase in stroke and in the actuator dimension. The choice of s2 is critical for the actuator design because it influences the size and the performances of the actuator. The optimal values proposed in equations (25), (30), (37) and (42) help the designer in optimizing the actuator architecture.

Parameter sF = FF/(K1SC (LC− L01)) quantifies the influence of dissipative forces on the stroke of the actuator and is the ratio between the dissipative force and the maximum force of the primary spring at low temperature. For low values of sF, the dissipative force is negligible in comparison with the forces expressed by the backup systems, and the actuator moves freely. The upper limit of sF is reached when the dissipative force becomes high enough to prevent the movement of the actuator. It is possible to cope with high values of sF by increasing the deflection and the stiffness of the primary spring, which leads to compact actuators with small strokes. Parameter sF is the other main design parameter of the actuator design process.

Parameter s0 is the equivalent of sF for the conservative force. Since the conservative force helps the backup system, high values of s0 improve the actuator performances. This parameter is proportional to sF and the conservative over dissipative force ratio, thus it cannot be used as a sensitive design parameter.

Considering the three different backup elements, the best performances in terms of size of the actuator for a given external load are obtained with the agonist–antagonist SMA spring design and not with a conventional spring, as shown by the comparison of Figures 6 and 8. Using a force as bias for the primary spring may be convenient when there is an important conservative force acting on the system, which may help the restoring process.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: An analytical design procedure was developed for binary shape memory actuators subjected to a general dissipative and conservative force system. Three cases of backup element were considered: bias provided by a constant force, by a conventional spring or by a second shape memory spring. Dimensionless, closed-form equations were developed, and optimal values for dimensionless parameters are provided. A step-by-step procedure is proposed for each of the three configurations, leading to the functional design of the whole actuator (primary spring and bias element). The proposed procedure is fairly general, and its application for the embodiment of the actuator with real elements in the form of helical springs, straight wires or other shapes is readily performed as shown in a previous article by the authors (Spinella and Dragoni, 2009).
